subject: Wild Cards Weekend
event:
No, no, not my Wild Cards books... NFL football.

All four road teams won.  So much for home field advantage.

"Life is miserable and full of pain," I often say, when the Giants and the Jets go down to defeat.  But I have to say, this weekend's games put my own miseries into proportion.  Yes, yes, the Jets have breaking my heart since 1969... but at least I am not a Vikings or a Bengals fan.  (Though I have friends who are both.  Hi, Mike.  Hi, Steve).  In all my years of watching football, I don't think I have ever seen two such agonizing losses.  If they had happened to one of my teams, I'd... I'd... god, I don't know what I'd do.  Talk about snatching defeat from the jaws of victory.

Next week it's on to the divisonal round.  Someone please beat the Patriots and I will be happy.

comments.article: i completely agree!
Each time I see your profile "gif", I wanna dance :P
This was a dark and painful day. Will never feel safe watching a kick again.

All 4 Wild Cards won, which has apparently never happened before. While I feel bad for the Vikings, (especially that Kicker, I hope he doesn't go on the internet ever again); I cannot bring myself to feel sorry for the Bengals. They earned that loss, that hit on Brown was insanity, Jones couldn't maintain composure, and Marvin Lewis did not have control of his team. The Steelers' had bad hits on Bengals as well, and their coaching staff was apparently provoking the Bengals throughout the contest, but the Bengals could not keep it under control. Still though, I hope that Denver goes ahead and knocks the battered Steelers out of the playoffs, because they don't deserve to be there either.

As for the Chiefs and your favorite team to hate, George, it really could go either way. I'm predicting a blowout for one side, It will either reestablish the Patriots' dominance and send them to the Super Bowl, or it will be more of the lukewarm effort we've been getting from the Patriots, and the Chiefs will capitalize. Should be interesting.
comments.subject: Wild Cards (The Television adaptation?)

comments.article:
I am German and my American husband has no clue about sports in general :P But I love soccer, at least the European and World cups. Did you ever visit one of these games ? If not: this year is the European cup and if you are in Europe (maybe for promo reasons), you should definately watch a game :)

PS: Will you be in Germany to promote your book? I would love to get a autograph :D
comments.subject: Could you warm up to soccer? :D

comments.article: It was a great day to be a Packers fan living in MN. That's all I'm gonna say.
One of the highlights of Arisia every year is sitting in the bar and secretly rooting against Evil Little Bill and his Minions.

Three of the four teams that won have been in the playoffs, have won in the playoffs, and aside from the chiefs, have won superbowls in the past ten years.  Winning in december takes discipline, and it takes a little something special to not be blinded by the bright lights of primetime.
comments.subject: It's about winning.

comments.article: The Chiefs are so due for a Superbowl win.
comments.subject: Re: It's about winning.

comments.article:
Hey George,

Do you watch the tennis?
comments.subject: Sport

comments.article: You could tell that the cold had both the Vikings and the Seahawks off their games.  Fortunately, I'm a Seattle fan.
I'm not much of a football fan. My mother, however, lived and died a Viking devotee. For her I watched, I cussed and I cried.
comments.subject: Not a Fan

comments.article:
It's not that surprising that all visiting teams won, given the policy of giving home field advantage to the division champions. In both conferences the worst team (according to record) was seeded #4 and played at home. Add to this the strong playoff experience of the visiting teams (Seattle, Pittsburgh, GB) vs home teams (Minnesota, Washington, Houston) and this was a clear possibility before the weekend started.

Here's a stat: Previous playoff experience of the visiting team starting QBs: 37 starts. Of home team starting QBs: 0 starts. Zero! Neither Cousins, Bridgewater, McCarron or Hoyer had started a playoff game before. Compare this with Roethlisberger (15 starts) or Rodgers (11).

Besides all that, the losses by Cincinnati and Minnesota were way too painful and undeserved.
comments.subject: Visiting teams

comments.article: Might do you some good to enjoy the run of excellence the Patriots have had on the field instead of letting it upset you. After Watching the behavior of the Bengals & the Steelers & the abject double standard of the media in not touching the Manning HGH story (HGH was sent to Manning's home in the name of his wife) the Brady bunch is not looking so bad these days....it could even be said that the league was, just perhaps, not being truthful. Just a thought:)

I have no interest in football, but my father does, so I briefly brought up the Chiefs winning this Saturday with him. He mentioned that next Saturday they'll be facing off against a team with a coach who he described in less than flattering terms, something along the lines of being soulless or some-such.

I responded:

"Let me guess. Is it Bill Belichick and the New England Patriots?"

And I got it in one. I don't really know any football couches, but even casual perusal of this blog's football posts has apparently given me enough familiarity to know "evil little bill" when he's being described.
As a Chiefs fan i hope your wish is fulfilled this weekend.

Hello George, if i can i want to ask You about something. We are asking authors "Why it is worth to read?" I would like to know your opinion/statement. Sorry for asking here, but we are small website and its difficult for us to have chance to ask famous writer abouts this. It would be really great if you answered for our question. Of course if You can`t we understood. All answers we publish on our website.

Best regards
Patrick
Kawerna.pl
comments.subject: Small question

comments.article: This week the Chiefs are my favorite team.

Watching how pitiful the Redskins were yesterday must give you hope. With the Cowboys having a 4th place schedule and the Giants having a 3rd place schedule, I guarantee both teams will be competing for the title next year.
comments.subject: NFC East

comments.article:
Can't believe we've lost Bowie today.

What a talent.
comments.subject: Off Topic

comments.article:
I have a couple friends who are Bengals fans, and several that root for Minnesota too. I personally don't follow the NFL closely enough to be heart-broken when my team loses, but I know that feeling. Fans will have nightmares about these games for years. My sister, a Raiders fan, still can't watch the
"Tuck Rule" footage and bares a strong dislike for both Tom Brady and Walt Coleman.

The Bangles earned their loss and all the anger that comes with it. Part of closing out a game is discipline. You play hard, but cautious. You can't hand over the game because you forgot to play by the rules. The team and the fans have every right to be mad at Pacman and particularly at Burfict. Then again, those fans were also throwing trash at an injured player being carted off. Hate the guy or not, there's no class in that so I don't feel for Bengals fans at all.

Minnesota, also earned their loss, but the hatred directed at Blair Walsh is misguided. Take Blair off the team and Minnesota would have 0 points on the board. According to the announcers this was the first field goal he missed all season. Professional or not, do something enough and it will go wrong eventually. I can understand their frustration - the guy is paid to do one thing and he failed at it, but the rest of the offense couldn't get a single touchdown either.
comments.subject: Wildcard nightmares

comments.article: EXACTLY ALL THIS. Also, what is it with the placeholder and the laces? Twice! Once they got it anyway, the second time, not so much.
comments.subject: Re: Wildcard nightmares

comments.article: As a Vikings fan...well, the North remembers, as it always does, and one of these years the mummer's farce will be done.

So The Bills hired Rob Ryan to come join his brother Rex. What do you think about that? I can't wait to see how they work together. Rob was the DC for Cleveland for awhile so I'm real familiar with him. I thought he did a good job considering the team he was working with. I know Rex is your Jets' old coach so I was curious what you think of the pairing.

The Bills are a decent team so this could be very interesting next season.
comments.subject: The Bills

comments.article:
Ever since my Alabama Crimson Tide lost to Auburn on a missed field goal that was run back for a TD on the last play with a second left, I just hurt for fans of teams that lose like the Bengals and Vikings did. Michigan's loss the Michigan State was similar too.

For me it was months before I had interest in football again after that loss.

Also speaking of football pain, did you see Coughlin is interviewing with the Eagles? How would you feel about him coaching a rival in the same division?
comments.subject: Painful defeat

comments.article: Poor Patriots team, you should not wish us those things. Games were fun.
comments.subject: ohhhh

comments.article: It seems that the Seahawks had Valarian steel with them, when they went up north to take on the wildings of Minnesota. lol!!!
comments.subject: Wild Card Weekend

comments.article: Felt so bad for Bengal's quarterback A.J. Maccaron, he played a truly decent second half, then tried to protect the win with a handoff to the running back, but one brutal lost fumble later followed by two truly boneheaded moves on defense, and Cincinnati loses. That cannot feel good.
comments.subject: Defeat

comments.article:
As an Eagles fan, I know pain. I can relate to what the Vikings fans are feeling. At least they lost on a football play. I can get my head around that.

Cincy, however. Just wow. Can you imagine sitting in a cold hard rain for 3+ hours, with all that emotion, taking the lead.. only to see the fumble, the 2 penalties, and then the long, cold, wet walk back to the car?

At least the Miracle at the Meadowlands part I, II, III and IV were football plays. (Sorry - couldn't resist.)
comments.subject: Cincy
